dataset.title: Salmon escapement data from Arcic-Yukon-Kusokwim Region, 1965-2015

creator.organizationName: Alaska Department of Fish and Game, Division of Commercial Fisheries, Arctic-Yukon-Kuskokwim Region

associatedParty.organizationName: National Center for Ecological Analysis and Synthesis

abstract.para:
The salmon life cycle begins in freshwater streams when adult salmon spawn, leaving fertilized eggs which hatch in the stream. Juvenile salmon migrate downstream to the ocean, where they spend several years until they reach reproductive age. Upon reaching sexual maturity, they return to their natal streams to spawn. The number of mature salmon migrating from the marine environment to freshwater streams is defined as escapement. Escapement data are the enumeration of these migrating fish as they pass upstream, and are a widely used index of spawning salmon abundance. These data are important for fisheries management, since most salmon harvest occurs in freshwater rivers during this migration.
Escapement data are collected in a variety of ways. Stationary projects utilize observers stationed along freshwater corridors who count salmon as they pass upriver through weirs or past elevated towers. Sonar equipment placed in the river can also give a stationary escapement count. These counts usually represent a sample, and are expanded to represent a 24h period. Escapement data can also be collected using aerial surveys, where observers in an aircraft provide an index to estimate escapement. In general, escapement counts do not represent total abundance, but instead an index of abundance. Surveys are usually timed to coincide with peak spawning activity, generally in the summer, but in the case of Coho salmon in the fall as well.
These data are the result of a multi-year effort by the Alaska Department of Fish and Game, Division of Commercial Fisheries, Arctic-Yukon-Kusokwim (AYK) Region to create a salmon database management system that centralizes AYK salmon data in a standard format, making the data more accessible to management agencies and the general public. The escapement data portion of this database includes data from more than 70 projects conducted by the Alaska Department of Fish and Game, federal agencies, non-governmental organizations, and the Canadian Department of Fisheries and Oceans. Data span the time period of 1965 to present, and were collected on 58 unique rivers in four management areas. These areas are Kotzebue, Kuskokwim, Norton Sound-Port Clarence, Yukon and Yukon-Canada. The five Alaskan salmon species (Chinook, Chum, Coho, Pink, Sockeye) are all represented in this dataset, in addition to two salmonids (Dolly Varden, Arctic Char).

intellectualRights.para:
In using AYK Database Management System (AYKDBMS) data, the user agrees to the following:
Not to use data contained in the AYKDBMS in any publication, product, or commercial application without prior written consent of the original data provider.
To cite both the data provider and the AYKDBMS appropriately after approval of use is obtained.
Not to hold the AYKDBMS or the original data providers liable for errors in the data.
While we have made every effort to ensure the quality of the database, we cannot guarantee the accuracy of these datasets.

geographicCoverage.geographicDescription: Arctic-Yukon-Kuskokwim Region in Alaska and Canada

section.title: Fish enumeration
section.para: Fish are counted as they pass upstream past observers along migration corridors. Fish are counted as they pass upriver through weirs, past observers in observation towers, by sonar equipment in the river, or by aerial survey. Four count types are indicated in the data: Calculated, Estimated, Counted Live, and Unknown. Calculated values indicate the sum of the fish counted over one day, multplied by a factor. Estimated values indicate data were not obtainable for an entire day or part of a day, so the data for that particular day are estimated based on data from days surrounding the missing day. Counted Live indicates similar methodologies to Calculated values. Unknown indicates the count type is not known.

section.title: Data concatenation
section.para: Data are recieved from the AYK Database Management System online form in excel (.xlsx) files for each unique river/species. In these data files, rows are fish enumerations on a unique date, and columns are unique year/method type combinations. Data for each river/species file are rearranged with rows containing unique date/year combinations, and columns indicating count type. Dates with no count value for a given method are populated with empty (NA) values. Individual, rearranged river/species files are then combined to a single file, populating new columns with river and species information. Columns for region, enumeration method (weir, tower, sonar), and participating agencies are also populated based on information from the AYK Database Mangement System website.

section.title: Data quality assurance
section.para: To ensure high quality data, the following checks are performed. Data for each unique year/enumeration method combination are summed and compared to the annual sum row from the original data files. Unique values for river, species, region, method type, and participating agency are found and examined to ensure there are no spelling errors or apparent alternate spellings. Some files include an annual sum with the date 01/01/YYYY - rows with dates in this format are removed. The range of escapement enumeration values for each enumeration method are examined to ensure values are reasonable.

section.title: Calculating season totals
section.para: Season totals are calculated for each unique year/river/species by summing across all four enumeration methods and dates for that year. If there are no data for a particular year, the empty value NA is preserved in the cumulative value. The cumulative season total is replicated across each date in that year/river/species and included as a new column in the concatenated dataset.

description.para: Data span from 1965-2016, and include data from 58 rivers in the management areas Kotzebue, Kuskokwim, Norton Sound-Port Clarence, Yukon and Yukon-Canada. 2016 data should be considered incomplete, however, since data were extracted prior to the end of the fall run for this year. Not all rivers contain continuous data from 1965 to present - the number of years and continuity of data varies considerably by river and species. Additionally, data for all species are not collected at all rivers.

samplingDescription.para: The data are a compilation of studies with varying sampling designs. Most utilize sonar, weirs, and towers to collect escapement data. Some utilize aerial surveys. Surveys are generally timed to capture peak spawning and the period immediately before and after the spawning event.

project.title: State of Alaska Salmon and People

personnel.organizationName: National Center for Ecological Analysis and Synthesis

attribute.attributeDefinition: The date (year, month, day) on which the escapement survey was conducted
Region where escapement survey was conducted. Region names are similar to Alaska Department of Fish and Game management areas in the Arctic-Yukon-Kusokwim Region.

codeDefinition.definition: Including Kuskokwim river drainage, all waters of Alaska flowing into the Bering Sea between Cape Newenham and the Noskonat Peninsula, and Nunivak and St. Matthew Islands
Including all waters that drain into Norton Sound, the Chukchi Sea, and the Bering Sea between Point Hope to Point Romanof, including the waters of Alaska surrounding St. Lawrence Island

Including all waters between the latitude of Point Romanof and the latitude of the westernmost point of the Naskonat Peninsula, including those waters draining into the Bering Sea and all waters of Alaska north of the latitude of the westernmost tip of Point Hope and those waters of Alaska draining into the Arctic Ocean and the Chukchi Sea to the north and east
Including all water of the Yukon River and its tributaries that drain the Yukon Territory and the province of British Columbia in Canada

attribute.attributeDefinition: Name of river or stream where escapement survey was conducted - i.e. the freshwater migration corridor salmon use to escape the marine fishery to spawn
Common name of salmon species for which escapement data were collected

codeDefinition.definition: scientific name Salvelinus alpinus
scientific name Oncorhynchus tshawytscha
scientific name Oncorhynchus keta
scientific name Oncorhynchus kisutch
anadromous Dolly Varden, scientific name Salvelinus malma
both anadromous and fluvial Dolly Varden, scientific name Salvelinus Malma
Other non-target species not belonging to salmonid family
scientific name Oncorhynchus nerka
unknown salmon of genus Oncorhyncus

attribute.attributeDefinition: All salmon species have migration runs that occur during the summer, but Coho have an additional fall run. Run type distinguishes these runs

codeDefinition.definition: summer run for all species except Coho
Fall run of Coho
Summer run of Coho
runs for Other (non-target) species are undefined

attribute.attributeDefinition: Escapement enumeration of the number of fish per day moving up a freshwater corridor to spawn, as calculated from the sum of fish counted in one day, multiplied by a factor
Escapement enumeration of the number of fish per day counted live moving up a freshwater corridor to spawn
Escapement enumeration of the number of fish per day moving up a freshwater corridor to spawn, as estimated from an observation period shorter than 24 hours.

missingValueCode.codeExplanation: no escapement counts recorded that year

attribute.attributeDefinition: Escapement enumeration of the number of fish per day moving up a freshwater corridor to spawn, with unknown counting method
Cumulative escapement count over a single season (year) for a unique river/species combination. This total represents the sum of all escapement values recorded, including all enumeration methods.
Method used to collect escapement numbers

codeDefinition.definition: Fish ladder used to collect escapement data
Sonar used to collect escapement data
Tower used to collect escapement data
Weir used to collect escapement data
Video footage used to collect esacpement data
both a weir and a tower used to collect escapement data
Method information is unknown

attribute.attributeDefinition: Name of agency or agencies that participated in/conducted the data collection project
